description.narrative: Förberedelse av ett uppskalningsbart program till Rural Energy Agency för eltillgång till landsbygden och genom förnyelsebara källor. Stöd till elreglersystem till reglermyndigheten för el- och vattenbolag i Tanzania. Finansieras genom en bilateral stödfond hanterad av Världsbanken.

Preparation of a rural/renewable access-scale up programme to the Rural Energy Agency. Support to the electricity regulatory system at the Electricity and Water Utitility Regulatory Authority in Tanzania. Financed by a single-donor trust fund (TF) managed by the World Bank.

Tanzania has abundant renewable energy resources that include hydropower, solar energy, wind, and biomass. Despite this significant potential, the renewable energy industry remains in its infancy, hindered by regulatory, financial, and technical capacity barriers.
In view of the low access rates that prevailed in Tanzania in the late 2000s, Sweden provided funding to support various interventions in the Tanzania energy sector through the Tanzania: Swedish Support to Electricity Access and Regulation in Tanzania (TF071411) Trust Fund (TF). A total amount of SEK 55 million (approximately US$ 7.8 million) funding was allocated to support renewable energy scale-up; energy access acceleration; and improvements in the electricity regulatory system. The Administrative Agreement for the TF was signed between the World Bank and Sweden in December 2009 and has been amended several times to accommodate and respond to changing sector needs. The TF was used to provide vital strategic support to supplement technical assistance resources to the Rural Energy Agency (REA), the Energy and Water Utilities Regulatory Authority (EWURA), and TANESCO under the World Bank funded Tanzania Energy Development and Access Expansion Project (TEDAP) and the Tanzania Rural Electrification Expansion Program (TREEP).
The SIDA TF provided instrumental support for successfully piloting bottom-up electrification approaches under TEDAP by assisting the sector institutions, local developers, and commercial banks to prepare a plausible project pipeline by undertaking the requisite technical, economic, and financial appraisal, transaction structuring that will facilitate financial closure, while also ensuring that the projects comply with the relevant environmental and social safeguards requirements. The TF also supported the formulation and operationalization of a working group comprising of REA, TANESCO and EWURA to analyze the technical, procurement and economic challenges to rural electrification expansion and to develop low-cost electrification expansion pilots for grid extension in rural areas.
The TF has also played a critical role in the preparation and implementation of TREEP, an innovative Program for Results (PforR) operation, which was approved by the World Banks Board of Directors on June 21, 2016, became effective in March 2017, and is currently in its fifth year of implementation. TREEPs Project Development Objectives are to: i) to increase access to electricity in rural areas; and (ii) to scale-up the supply of renewable energy in rural areas while strengthening sector institutional capacity. SIDA TF resources have been critical in the implementation supervision support of TREEP, especially the independent verification annual results reported by REA. The TF has also supported the engagement between commercial banks (participating financial institutions (PFIs)) and private sector renewable energy, that can potentially benefit for TREEP credit line (CL) programs. The TF has also supported a mobilization and awareness campaign program to equip communities with the necessary information to make informed decisions when applying for electricity connections.
Development Objective and Program Description The Trust Fund had two objectives. Firstly, it aimed to assist REA and other sector stakeholders to build capacity to develop, finance and implement a scaled-up on-grid and off-grid rural electrification program with main emphasis on renewable energy development. Secondly, it aimed to assist EWURA to gain capacity to develop a regulatory system to strengthen and monitor the performance of TANESCO, Small Power Producers (SPPs), and other sector players and enterprises.
Progress towards achieving the programs objectives was measured by the following indicators: - Access scale-up approach consolidated, involving not only support for bottom-up initiatives piloted by TEDAP, but also the REA-led grid extension works; and - A regulatory system for reviewing the power purchase costs from large Independent Power Producers (IPPs), promoting efficient and financially sustainable grid and off-grid Small Power Producers (SPPs) and the development and implementation of credible systems to monitor the commercial, financial, and operational performance of TANESCO and other sector enterprises.
This Conclusion on Performance provides an overview of the major achievements and activities supported under the Sida TF during the period from January 2020 to December 2020. It also provide the lessons learnt during the implementation period.

description.narrative:
The following summary provides an overview of the major achievements and activities supported under the Sida TF during the period from January- December 2020. During the during the reporting period between January and December 2020, the focus of the TF activities was to: (i) continue support to the off-grid electrification components (SPP and Renewable Energy Company (REC) credit lines) under TREEP; (ii) support the independent verification of results achieved TREEP; and (iii) support REAs safeguards capacity strengthening activities.
Progress under each of these activities is set out below: Off-grid electrification components: The TF resources were used to provide continued technical assistance for the operationalization of the SPP/REC credit lines. While there has been limited progress under the SPP/REC credit line programs, there are now seven SPPAs that were between TANESCO and the developers in December 2020 and March 2021. This is an encouraging step in terms of SPPs that can potentially use the available funding under this program. Out of the seven SPP developers, three have already made loan applications to Tanzania Investment Bank (TIB), the fund manager of the program, for a total of US$ 9 million and 11 MW. In addition, the TF was used to provide targeted advisory to REA, following which REA approved recommendations to reduce interest and refinancing rates. Support under the TF also enabled TIB to become a PFI under the SPP/REC credit line, both as a direct and syndicated lender, to increase the uptake of both CLs. A due diligence has already been completed by the Banks team to assess TIBs capability to act as a PFI both by itself and in syndication with commercial banks and TIBs application for direct lending has recently been approved by the Bank of Tanzania.
Independent verification of results: Owing to the TF resources, the IVA continued to play a key role in the verification of results and strengthening REAs Trust Agent capacity and improving its performance to carry out verification. The improvement in the percentage of eligible connections over reported connections is a clear indication of the impact of this support. In August 2020, a disbursement of US$ 38.9 million was completed against the Year 3 IVA results which verified 144,024 eligible connections (99.9 percent eligible connections over reported connections). From the Year 4 results report 99.6 percent of the reported 280,741 connections were confirmed eligible by the IVA and US$ 11 million was disbursed against the results.
Overall supervision and support for REAs safeguards strengthening: Safeguards system strengthening, monitoring and reporting remains a high priority for the Bank and is critical to deliver sustainable and equitable infrastructure services. Following the shortfalls in safeguards implementation that were reported in 2018/19 and TANESCOs inability to recruit safeguards staff for regional offices, the TF resources were used to help REA contract a Project Management Consultant (PMC) to support the design, procurement, supervision, verification and reporting on grid extensions contract works. The PMC has been on the ground since August 2020 and has been supporting REA in the preparation of bidding documents and the procurement of grid extension work under REA3Round2, the preparation of safeguards monitoring and reporting framework and carrying out of safeguard training for the awarded contractors. The last focus area was co-financed by the World Bank supervision budget. The TF resources have provided critical additionality and necessary just-in-time support that would not have been possible or available solely through Bank funding.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
